2025 UT S 3
Author: Stevenson
Version: Introduced
Version Date: 03/07/2025

Appropriations Adjustments

2025 GENERAL SESSION

STATE OF UTAH

Chief Sponsor: Jerry W. Stevenson

House Sponsor: Val L. Peterson

LONG TITLE

General Description:

This bill supplements or reduces appropriations otherwise provided for the support and operation of state government for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2024 and ending June 30, 2025 and for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2025 and ending June 30, 2026.

Highlighted Provisions:

This bill:

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain state agencies;

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain public education programs;

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain institutions of higher education;

• provides funds for the bills with fiscal impact passed in the 2025 General Session;

• provides budget increases and decreases for other purposes as described; and

• provides intent language.

Money Appropriated in this Bill:

This bill appropriates ($87,406,900) in operating and capital budgets for fiscal year 2025, including:

• ($13,542,400) from General Fund; and

• $390,600 from Income Tax Fund; and

• ($74,255,100) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($5,630,000) in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $100,050,400 in business-like activities for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $285,000 in restricted fund and account transfers for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $400 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $279,093,100 in operating and capital budgets for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $46,942,500 from General Fund; and

• ($91,797,600) from Income Tax Fund; and

• $15,322,300 from Uniform School Fund; and

• $308,625,900 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $7,975,800 in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $500,000 from General Fund; and

• $7,475,800 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($14,027,700) in business-like activities for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $630,000 from General Fund; and

• ($14,657,700) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $118,318,600 in restricted fund and account transfers for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $15,731,000 from General Fund; and

• $102,587,600 from Income Tax Fund.

This bill appropriates $842,101,800 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year 2026, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $298,813,400 in capital project funds for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $2,000,000 from General Fund; and

• $296,813,400 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill reflects $7,306,100 in higher education budget reporting for fiscal year 2026.

Other Special Clauses:

This bill provides a special effective date.

Section 1 of this bill takes effect immediately. Section 2 of this bill takes effect on July 1, 2025.

Uncodified Material Affected:

ENACTS UNCODIFIED MATERIAL

UNIVERSITY OF UTAH
ITEM 306 To University of Utah - Education and General
From General Fund 16,000,000
From General Fund, One-time (28,000)
From Income Tax Fund (15,500,000)
From Income Tax Fund, One-time 1,330,000
Schedule of Programs:
Research 1,500,000
Public Service 302,000
The Legislature intends that the University of
Utah use $1,500,000 one-time funding provided by this
item to fund a cross-departmental project to incorporate
an odometry lab and a proof of concept for
communications-based train control on a limited portion
of a light rail vehicle line. The goal of this project is to
determine the best and most appropriate signaling system
for current and future transit operations in the Salt Lake
Valley, and to promote a center of excellence at the
University of Utah for such systems.
The Legislature intends that the appropriations of
$300,000 to the University of Utah's Hinckley Institute of
Politics and $300,000 to Utah Valley University's Gary
R. Herbert Institute for Public Policy be used by the two
institutions to collaborate on a proposal to host
nonpartisan candidate debates and on establishing a
statewide, nonpartisan debate organization. The
statewide, nonpartisan debate organization shall be
located at the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the
University of Utah. This organization shall ensure that
candidate debates for federal and statewide elected
offices are objective, accessible, and of high quality. To
promote broad geographic accessibility and statewide
engagement, the two institutions shall ensure there are
debates at degree-granting higher education campuses
throughout the state. The Legislature emphasizes the
nonpartisan nature of this initiative and expects the two
institutions to coordinate their efforts to foster civic
engagement, voter education, and public discourse
through structured debates and related activities. The
Legislature further intends that these funds not lapse at
the close of FY 2026.

From General Fund, One-time 1,000,000
From Income Tax Fund (555,400)
Schedule of Programs:
Pass Through Funding 444,600
The Legislature intends that Talent Ready Utah,
in consultation with and upon recommendation from the
First Credential Oversight Committee established in
First Credential Program (House Bill 260, 2025
General Session) use up to $1,000,000 one-time
appropriated for Higher Education Digital Credentials,
Pathways, and Program Mapping to contract with a
vendor to develop a tool to provide skills portfolios to
students as they earn credentials in public high school
and through higher education certificate or degree
attainment. The Legislature further intends that this tool
ensures that students can track the development of
competencies obtained through coursework,
certifications, apprenticeships, and degrees and how
these competencies align with workforce demands and
potential employers.
The Legislature intends that the $4,000,000
ongoing Income Tax Fund appropriation in New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations (Senate Bill 2, 2025
General Session), Item 89, be allocated towards the direct
costs associated with expanding and creating Engineering
and Computer Science degree programs at Utah System
of Higher Education degree-granting institutions. The
Legislature further intends that the Engineering and
Computer Science Initiatives require a one-to-one match
from degree-granting institutions recommended to
receive the funding, and that Talent Ready Utah develop
processes and issue a grant application process to manage
and prioritize the distribution of funds. Institutions
submitting proposals must provide detailed plans for
program expansion or creation, including requested
direct programmatic delivery costs, equipment and
supply needs, curriculum development, use of matching
funds, anticipated student outcomes (enrollment,
completion, relevant placements), industry partnerships,
integration of work-based learning, expected delivery
timelines, and other relevant details. The Legislature
further intends that new investments be directed toward
expanding Engineering and Computer Science offerings,
addressing emerging occupations, and modernizing lab
equipment.

The Legislature intends that the State Board of
Education, in consultation with and upon
recommendation from the First Credential Oversight
Committee establish the First Credential Program
(House Bill 260, 2025 General Session) to use up to
$2,000,000 one-time appropriated for the expansion of
the Utah First Credential program to contract with a
vendor to develop an online system that offers a
statewide education and career mapping software
platform that is linked to state career opportunities and
offers a career interest aptitude assessment. The
Legislature further intends that the platform serve as a
comprehensive interactive tool for students, parents,
industry, and public educators to map high school
credentials through higher education certificate or degree
attainment.

Education use remaining funds appropriated for the Utah
First Credential Expansion funding item be distributed to
local education agencies using a grant process in
alignment with criteria established by the First Credential
Oversight Committee.

Section 3. Effective Date.

(1) Except as provided in Subsection (2), this bill takes effect:

(a) except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), May 7, 2025; or

(b) if approved by two-thirds of all members elected to each house:

(i) upon approval by the governor;

(ii) without the governor's signature, the day following the constitutional time limit of Utah Constitution, Article VII, Section 8; or

(iii) in the case of a veto, the date of veto override.

(2) The actions affecting Section 2 (Effective 07/01/25) take effect on July 1, 2025.

**Appropriations Adjustments**

2025 GENERAL SESSION

STATE OF UTAH

**Chief Sponsor: Jerry W. Stevenson**

House Sponsor: Val L. Peterson

**LONG TITLE**

**General Description:**

This bill supplements or reduces appropriations otherwise provided for the
support and operation of state government for the fiscal year beginning July
1, 2024 and ending June 30, 2025 and for the fiscal year beginning July 1,
2025 and ending June 30, 2026.

**Highlighted Provisions:**

This bill:

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
state agencies;

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
public education programs;

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
institutions of higher education;

 provides funds for the bills with fiscal impact passed in the 2025 General
Session;

 provides budget increases and decreases for other purposes as described; and

 provides intent language.

**Money Appropriated in this Bill:**

This bill appropriates ($87,406,900) in operating and capital budgets for
fiscal year 2025, including:

 ($13,542,400) from General Fund; and

 $390,600 from Income Tax Fund; and

 ($74,255,100) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($5,630,000) in expendable funds and accounts for
fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this
bill.

This bill appropriates $100,050,400 in business-like activities for fiscal
year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $285,000 in restricted fund and account transfers for
fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $400 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year
2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $279,093,100 in operating and capital budgets for
fiscal year 2026, including:

 $46,942,500 from General Fund; and

 ($91,797,600) from Income Tax Fund; and

 $15,322,300 from Uniform School Fund; and

 $308,625,900 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $7,975,800 in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal
year 2026, including:

 $500,000 from General Fund; and

 $7,475,800 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($14,027,700) in business-like activities for fiscal
year 2026, including:

 $630,000 from General Fund; and

 ($14,657,700) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $118,318,600 in restricted fund and account transfers
for fiscal year 2026, including:

 $15,731,000 from General Fund; and

 $102,587,600 from Income Tax Fund.

This bill appropriates $842,101,800 in transfers to unrestricted funds for
fiscal year 2026, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $298,813,400 in capital project funds for fiscal year
2026, including:

 $2,000,000 from General Fund; and

 $296,813,400 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill reflects $7,306,100 in higher education budget reporting for fiscal
year 2026.

**Other Special Clauses:**

This bill provides a special effective date.

Section 1 of this bill takes effect immediately. Section 2 of this bill takes
effect on July 1, 2025.

**Uncodified Material Affected:**

ENACTS UNCODIFIED MATERIAL

ITEM 306 | To University of Utah - Education and General |  |   
| From General Fund |  | 16,000,000

| From Income Tax Fund |  | (15,500,000)

| Schedule of Programs: |  |   
| Research | 1,500,000 |   
| Public Service | 302,000 |   
| The Legislature intends that the University of |  |   
| Utah use $1,500,000 one-time funding provided by this |  |   
| item to fund a cross-departmental project to incorporate |  |   
| an odometry lab and a proof of concept for |  |   
| communications-based train control on a limited portion |  |   
| of a light rail vehicle line. The goal of this project is to |  |   
| determine the best and most appropriate signaling system |  |   
| for current and future transit operations in the Salt Lake |  |   
| Valley, and to promote a center of excellence at the |  |   
| University of Utah for such systems. |  |   
| The Legislature intends that the appropriations of |  |   
| $300,000 to the University of Utah's Hinckley Institute of |  |   
| Politics and $300,000 to Utah Valley University's Gary |  |   
| R. Herbert Institute for Public Policy be used by the two |  |   
| institutions to collaborate on a proposal to host |  |   
| nonpartisan candidate debates and on establishing a |  |   
| statewide, nonpartisan debate organization. The |  |   
| statewide, nonpartisan debate organization shall be |  |   
| located at the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the |  |   
| University of Utah. This organization shall ensure that |  |   
| candidate debates for federal and statewide elected |  |   
| offices are objective, accessible, and of high quality. To |  |   
| promote broad geographic accessibility and statewide |  |   
| engagement, the two institutions shall ensure there are |  |   
| debates at degree-granting higher education campuses |  |   
| throughout the state. The Legislature emphasizes the |  |   
| nonpartisan nature of this initiative and expects the two |  |   
| institutions to coordinate their efforts to foster civic |  |   
| engagement, voter education, and public discourse |  |   
| through structured debates and related activities. The |  |   
| Legislature further intends that these funds not lapse at |  |   
| the close of FY 2026. |  |

| The Legislature intends that Talent Ready Utah, |  |   
| in consultation with and upon recommendation from the |  |   
| First Credential Oversight Committee established in |  |   
| First Credential Program (House Bill 260, 2025 |  |   
| General Session) use up to $1,000,000 one-time |  |   
| appropriated for Higher Education Digital Credentials, |  |   
| Pathways, and Program Mapping to contract with a |  |   
| vendor to develop a tool to provide skills portfolios to |  |   
| students as they earn credentials in public high school |  |   
| and through higher education certificate or degree |  |   
| attainment. The Legislature further intends that this tool |  |   
| ensures that students can track the development of |  |   
| competencies obtained through coursework, |  |   
| certifications, apprenticeships, and degrees and how |  |   
| these competencies align with workforce demands and |  |   
| potential employers. |  |   
| The Legislature intends that the $4,000,000 |  |   
| ongoing Income Tax Fund appropriation in New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations (Senate Bill 2, 2025 |  |   
| General Session), Item 89, be allocated towards the direct |  |   
| costs associated with expanding and creating Engineering |  |   
| and Computer Science degree programs at Utah System |  |   
| of Higher Education degree-granting institutions. The |  |   
| Legislature further intends that the Engineering and |  |   
| Computer Science Initiatives require a one-to-one match |  |   
| from degree-granting institutions recommended to |  |   
| receive the funding, and that Talent Ready Utah develop |  |   
| processes and issue a grant application process to manage |  |   
| and prioritize the distribution of funds. Institutions |  |   
| submitting proposals must provide detailed plans for |  |   
| program expansion or creation, including requested |  |   
| direct programmatic delivery costs, equipment and |  |   
| supply needs, curriculum development, use of matching |  |   
| funds, anticipated student outcomes (enrollment, |  |   
| completion, relevant placements), industry partnerships, |  |   
| integration of work-based learning, expected delivery |  |   
| timelines, and other relevant details. The Legislature |  |   
| further intends that new investments be directed toward |  |   
| expanding Engineering and Computer Science offerings, |  |   
| addressing emerging occupations, and modernizing lab |  |   
| equipment. |  |

2025 UT S 3
Author: Stevenson
Version: Enrolled
Version Date: 03/13/2025

Appropriations Adjustments

2025 GENERAL SESSION

STATE OF UTAH

Chief Sponsor: Jerry W. Stevenson

House Sponsor: Val L. Peterson

LONG TITLE

General Description:

This bill supplements or reduces appropriations otherwise provided for the support and operation of state government for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2024 and ending June 30, 2025 and for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2025 and ending June 30, 2026.

Highlighted Provisions:

This bill:

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain state agencies;

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain public education programs;

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain institutions of higher education;

• provides funds for the bills with fiscal impact passed in the 2025 General Session;

• provides budget increases and decreases for other purposes as described; and

• provides intent language.

Money Appropriated in this Bill:

This bill appropriates ($87,406,900) in operating and capital budgets for fiscal year 2025, including:

• ($13,542,400) from General Fund; and

• $390,600 from Income Tax Fund; and

• ($74,255,100) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($5,630,000) in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $100,050,400 in business-like activities for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $285,000 in restricted fund and account transfers for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $400 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $279,093,100 in operating and capital budgets for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $46,942,500 from General Fund; and

• ($91,797,600) from Income Tax Fund; and

• $15,322,300 from Uniform School Fund; and

• $308,625,900 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $7,975,800 in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $500,000 from General Fund; and

• $7,475,800 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($14,027,700) in business-like activities for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $630,000 from General Fund; and

• ($14,657,700) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $118,318,600 in restricted fund and account transfers for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $15,731,000 from General Fund; and

• $102,587,600 from Income Tax Fund.

This bill appropriates $842,101,800 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year 2026, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $298,813,400 in capital project funds for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $2,000,000 from General Fund; and

• $296,813,400 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill reflects $7,306,100 in higher education budget reporting for fiscal year 2026.

Other Special Clauses:

This bill provides a special effective date.

Section 1 of this bill takes effect immediately. Section 2 of this bill takes effect on July 1, 2025.

Uncodified Material Affected:

ENACTS UNCODIFIED MATERIAL

HIGHER EDUCATION
UNIVERSITY OF UTAH
ITEM 306 To University of Utah - Education and General
From General Fund 16,000,000
From General Fund, One-time (28,000)
From Income Tax Fund (15,500,000)
From Income Tax Fund, One-time 1,330,000
Schedule of Programs:
Research 1,500,000
Public Service 302,000
The Legislature intends that the University of
Utah use $1,500,000 one-time funding provided by this
item to fund a cross-departmental project to incorporate
an odometry lab and a proof of concept for
communications-based train control on a limited portion
of a light rail vehicle line. The goal of this project is to
determine the best and most appropriate signaling system
for current and future transit operations in the Salt Lake
Valley, and to promote a center of excellence at the
University of Utah for such systems.
The Legislature intends that the appropriations of
$300,000 to the University of Utah's Hinckley Institute of
Politics and $300,000 to Utah Valley University's Gary
R. Herbert Institute for Public Policy be used by the two
institutions to collaborate on a proposal to host
nonpartisan candidate debates and on establishing a
statewide, nonpartisan debate organization. The
statewide, nonpartisan debate organization shall be
located at the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the
University of Utah. This organization shall ensure that
candidate debates for federal and statewide elected
offices are objective, accessible, and of high quality. To
promote broad geographic accessibility and statewide
engagement, the two institutions shall ensure there are
debates at degree-granting higher education campuses
throughout the state. The Legislature emphasizes the
nonpartisan nature of this initiative and expects the two
institutions to coordinate their efforts to foster civic
engagement, voter education, and public discourse
through structured debates and related activities. The
Legislature further intends that these funds not lapse at
the close of FY 2026.

ITEM 313 To Utah Board of Higher Education - Administration
From Income Tax Fund (500,000)
From Income Tax Fund, One-time 100,000
Schedule of Programs:
Administration (500,000)
Pass Through Funding 100,000
The Legislature intends that the Utah Board of
Higher Education transfer any remaining balances from
the $3,264,600 appropriated in Item 134 of "New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations" (Senate Bill 2, 2023
General Session), to the Nucleus Institute for higher
education initiatives that advance innovation and
commercialization through increasing student
engagement and student project-based learning,
convening and sponsoring events, and providing grants
or other activities that promote innovation and
commercialization. The Legislature further intends that
the Utah Board of Higher Education transfer any
remaining balances from the $1,750,000 appropriated in
Item 144 of "New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations" (House Bill 2, 2024 General Session), to
the Nucleus Institute to be used to support Innovation
Districts in the state of Utah at the close of fiscal year
2025. The Legislature further intends that the Utah Board
of Higher Education transfer $800,000 in any remaining
Innovation District at the Point fund balances to the
Nucleus Institute at the close of fiscal year 2025.
The Legislature intends that the Board of Higher
Education distribute this $100,000 one-time
appropriation for Western Heritage equitably to eligible
institutions.

ITEM 316 To Utah Board of Higher Education - Talent Ready Utah
From General Fund, One-time 1,000,000
From Income Tax Fund (555,400)
Schedule of Programs:
Pass Through Funding 444,600
The Legislature intends that Talent Ready Utah,
in consultation with and upon recommendation from the
First Credential Oversight Committee established in
First Credential Program (House Bill 260, 2025
General Session) use up to $1,000,000 one-time
appropriated for Higher Education Digital Credentials,
Pathways, and Program Mapping to contract with a
vendor to develop a tool to provide skills portfolios to
students as they earn credentials in public high school
and through higher education certificate or degree
attainment. The Legislature further intends that this tool
ensures that students can track the development of
competencies obtained through coursework,
certifications, apprenticeships, and degrees and how
these competencies align with workforce demands and
potential employers.
The Legislature intends that the $4,000,000
ongoing Income Tax Fund appropriation in "New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations" (Senate Bill 2, 2025
General Session), Item 89, be allocated towards the direct
costs associated with expanding and creating Engineering
and Computer Science degree programs at Utah System
of Higher Education degree-granting institutions. The
Legislature further intends that the Engineering and
Computer Science Initiatives require a one-to-one match
from degree-granting institutions recommended to
receive the funding, and that Talent Ready Utah develop
processes and issue a grant application process to manage
and prioritize the distribution of funds. Institutions
submitting proposals must provide detailed plans for
program expansion or creation, including requested
direct programmatic delivery costs, equipment and
supply needs, curriculum development, use of matching
funds, anticipated student outcomes (enrollment,
completion, relevant placements), industry partnerships,
integration of work-based learning, expected delivery
timelines, and other relevant details. The Legislature
further intends that new investments be directed toward
expanding Engineering and Computer Science offerings,
addressing emerging occupations, and modernizing lab
equipment.

To implement the provisions of First Credential

The Legislature intends that the State Board of
Education, in consultation with and upon
recommendation from the First Credential Oversight
Committee establish the First Credential Program
(House Bill 260, 2025 General Session) to use up to
$2,000,000 one-time appropriated for the expansion of
the Utah First Credential program to contract with a
vendor to develop an online system that offers a
statewide education and career mapping software
platform that is linked to state career opportunities and
offers a career interest aptitude assessment. The
Legislature further intends that the platform serve as a
comprehensive interactive tool for students, parents,
industry, and public educators to map high school
credentials through higher education certificate or degree
attainment.
The Legislature intends that the State Board of
Education use remaining funds appropriated for the Utah
First Credential Expansion funding item be distributed to
local education agencies using a grant process in
alignment with criteria established by the First Credential
Oversight Committee.

Section 3. Effective Date.

(1) Except as provided in Subsection (2), this bill takes effect:

(a) except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), May 7, 2025; or

(b) if approved by two-thirds of all members elected to each house:

(i) upon approval by the governor;

(ii) without the governor's signature, the day following the constitutional time limit of Utah Constitution, Article VII, Section 8; or

(iii) in the case of a veto, the date of veto override.

(2) The actions affecting Section 2 (Effective 07/01/25) take effect on July 1, 2025.

**Appropriations Adjustments**

2025 GENERAL SESSION

STATE OF UTAH

**Chief Sponsor: Jerry W. Stevenson**

House Sponsor: Val L. Peterson

**LONG TITLE**

**General Description:**

This bill supplements or reduces appropriations otherwise provided for the
support and operation of state government for the fiscal year beginning July
1, 2024 and ending June 30, 2025 and for the fiscal year beginning July 1,
2025 and ending June 30, 2026.

**Highlighted Provisions:**

This bill:

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
state agencies;

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
public education programs;

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
institutions of higher education;

 provides funds for the bills with fiscal impact passed in the 2025 General
Session;

 provides budget increases and decreases for other purposes as described; and

 provides intent language.

**Money Appropriated in this Bill:**

This bill appropriates ($87,406,900) in operating and capital budgets for
fiscal year 2025, including:

 ($13,542,400) from General Fund; and

 $390,600 from Income Tax Fund; and

 ($74,255,100) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($5,630,000) in expendable funds and accounts for
fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this
bill.

This bill appropriates $100,050,400 in business-like activities for fiscal
year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $285,000 in restricted fund and account transfers for
fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $400 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year
2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $279,093,100 in operating and capital budgets for
fiscal year 2026, including:

 $46,942,500 from General Fund; and

 ($91,797,600) from Income Tax Fund; and

 $15,322,300 from Uniform School Fund; and

 $308,625,900 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $7,975,800 in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal
year 2026, including:

 $500,000 from General Fund; and

 $7,475,800 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($14,027,700) in business-like activities for fiscal
year 2026, including:

 $630,000 from General Fund; and

 ($14,657,700) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $118,318,600 in restricted fund and account transfers
for fiscal year 2026, including:

 $15,731,000 from General Fund; and

 $102,587,600 from Income Tax Fund.

This bill appropriates $842,101,800 in transfers to unrestricted funds for
fiscal year 2026, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $298,813,400 in capital project funds for fiscal year
2026, including:

 $2,000,000 from General Fund; and

 $296,813,400 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill reflects $7,306,100 in higher education budget reporting for fiscal
year 2026.

**Other Special Clauses:**

This bill provides a special effective date.

Section 1 of this bill takes effect immediately. Section 2 of this bill takes
effect on July 1, 2025.

**Uncodified Material Affected:**

ENACTS UNCODIFIED MATERIAL

ITEM 306 | To University of Utah - Education and General |  |   
| From General Fund |  | 16,000,000  
| From General Fund, One-time |  | (28,000)  
| From Income Tax Fund |  | (15,500,000)  
| From Income Tax Fund, One-time |  | 1,330,000  
| Schedule of Programs: |  |   
| Research | 1,500,000 |   
| Public Service | 302,000 |   
| The Legislature intends that the University of |  |   
| Utah use $1,500,000 one-time funding provided by this |  |   
| item to fund a cross-departmental project to incorporate |  |   
| an odometry lab and a proof of concept for |  |   
| communications-based train control on a limited portion |  |   
| of a light rail vehicle line. The goal of this project is to |  |   
| determine the best and most appropriate signaling system |  |   
| for current and future transit operations in the Salt Lake |  |   
| Valley, and to promote a center of excellence at the |  |   
| University of Utah for such systems. |  |   
| The Legislature intends that the appropriations of |  |   
| $300,000 to the University of Utah's Hinckley Institute of |  |   
| Politics and $300,000 to Utah Valley University's Gary |  |   
| R. Herbert Institute for Public Policy be used by the two |  |   
| institutions to collaborate on a proposal to host |  |   
| nonpartisan candidate debates and on establishing a |  |   
| statewide, nonpartisan debate organization. The |  |   
| statewide, nonpartisan debate organization shall be |  |   
| located at the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the |  |   
| University of Utah. This organization shall ensure that |  |   
| candidate debates for federal and statewide elected |  |   
| offices are objective, accessible, and of high quality. To |  |   
| promote broad geographic accessibility and statewide |  |   
| engagement, the two institutions shall ensure there are |  |   
| debates at degree-granting higher education campuses |  |   
| throughout the state. The Legislature emphasizes the |  |   
| nonpartisan nature of this initiative and expects the two |  |   
| institutions to coordinate their efforts to foster civic |  |   
| engagement, voter education, and public discourse |  |   
| through structured debates and related activities. The |  |   
| Legislature further intends that these funds not lapse at |  |   
| the close of FY 2026. |  |

| The Legislature intends that Talent Ready Utah, |  |   
| in consultation with and upon recommendation from the |  |   
| First Credential Oversight Committee established in |  |   
| First Credential Program (House Bill 260, 2025 |  |   
| General Session) use up to $1,000,000 one-time |  |   
| appropriated for Higher Education Digital Credentials, |  |   
| Pathways, and Program Mapping to contract with a |  |   
| vendor to develop a tool to provide skills portfolios to |  |   
| students as they earn credentials in public high school |  |   
| and through higher education certificate or degree |  |   
| attainment. The Legislature further intends that this tool |  |   
| ensures that students can track the development of |  |   
| competencies obtained through coursework, |  |   
| certifications, apprenticeships, and degrees and how |  |   
| these competencies align with workforce demands and |  |   
| potential employers. |  |   
| The Legislature intends that the $4,000,000 |  |   
| ongoing Income Tax Fund appropriation in "New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations" (Senate Bill 2, 2025 |  |   
| General Session), Item 89, be allocated towards the direct |  |   
| costs associated with expanding and creating Engineering |  |   
| and Computer Science degree programs at Utah System |  |   
| of Higher Education degree-granting institutions. The |  |   
| Legislature further intends that the Engineering and |  |   
| Computer Science Initiatives require a one-to-one match |  |   
| from degree-granting institutions recommended to |  |   
| receive the funding, and that Talent Ready Utah develop |  |   
| processes and issue a grant application process to manage |  |   
| and prioritize the distribution of funds. Institutions |  |   
| submitting proposals must provide detailed plans for |  |   
| program expansion or creation, including requested |  |   
| direct programmatic delivery costs, equipment and |  |   
| supply needs, curriculum development, use of matching |  |   
| funds, anticipated student outcomes (enrollment, |  |   
| completion, relevant placements), industry partnerships, |  |   
| integration of work-based learning, expected delivery |  |   
| timelines, and other relevant details. The Legislature |  |   
| further intends that new investments be directed toward |  |   
| expanding Engineering and Computer Science offerings, |  |   
| addressing emerging occupations, and modernizing lab |  |   
| equipment. |  |

2025 UT S 3
Author: Stevenson
Version: Enacted - Line Item Vetoed
Version Date: 03/27/2025

S.B. 3 Enrolled

Appropriations Adjustments

2025 GENERAL SESSION

STATE OF UTAH

Chief Sponsor: Jerry W. Stevenson

House Sponsor: Val L. Peterson

LONG TITLE

General Description:

This bill supplements or reduces appropriations otherwise provided for the support and operation of state government for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2024 and ending June 30, 2025 and for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2025 and ending June 30, 2026.

Highlighted Provisions:

This bill:

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain state agencies;

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain public education programs;

• provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain institutions of higher education;

• provides funds for the bills with fiscal impact passed in the 2025 General Session;

• provides budget increases and decreases for other purposes as described; and

• provides intent language.

Money Appropriated in this Bill:

This bill appropriates ($87,406,900) in operating and capital budgets for fiscal year 2025, including:

• ($13,542,400) from General Fund; and

• $390,600 from Income Tax Fund; and

• ($74,255,100) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($5,630,000) in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $100,050,400 in business-like activities for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $285,000 in restricted fund and account transfers for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $400 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $279,093,100 in operating and capital budgets for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $46,942,500 from General Fund; and

• ($91,797,600) from Income Tax Fund; and

• $15,322,300 from Uniform School Fund; and

• $308,625,900 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $7,975,800 in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $500,000 from General Fund; and

• $7,475,800 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($14,027,700) in business-like activities for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $630,000 from General Fund; and

• ($14,657,700) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $118,318,600 in restricted fund and account transfers for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $15,731,000 from General Fund; and

• $102,587,600 from Income Tax Fund.

This bill appropriates $842,101,800 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year 2026, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $298,813,400 in capital project funds for fiscal year 2026, including:

• $2,000,000 from General Fund; and

• $296,813,400 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill reflects $7,306,100 in higher education budget reporting for fiscal year 2026.

Other Special Clauses:

This bill provides a special effective date.

Section 1 of this bill takes effect immediately. Section 2 of this bill takes effect on July 1, 2025.

Uncodified Material Affected:

ENACTS UNCODIFIED MATERIAL

Be it enacted by the Legislature of the state of Utah:

HIGHER EDUCATION
UNIVERSITY OF UTAH
ITEM 306 To University of Utah - Education and General
From General Fund 16,000,000
From General Fund, One-time (28,000)
From Income Tax Fund (15,500,000)
From Income Tax Fund, One-time 1,330,000
Schedule of Programs:
Research 1,500,000
Public Service 302,000
The Legislature intends that the University of
Utah use $1,500,000 one-time funding provided by this
item to fund a cross-departmental project to incorporate
an odometry lab and a proof of concept for
communications-based train control on a limited portion
of a light rail vehicle line. The goal of this project is to
determine the best and most appropriate signaling system
for current and future transit operations in the Salt Lake
Valley, and to promote a center of excellence at the
University of Utah for such systems.
The Legislature intends that the appropriations of
$300,000 to the University of Utah's Hinckley Institute of
Politics and $300,000 to Utah Valley University's Gary
R. Herbert Institute for Public Policy be used by the two
institutions to collaborate on a proposal to host
nonpartisan candidate debates and on establishing a
statewide, nonpartisan debate organization. The
statewide, nonpartisan debate organization shall be
located at the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the
University of Utah. This organization shall ensure that
candidate debates for federal and statewide elected
offices are objective, accessible, and of high quality. To
promote broad geographic accessibility and statewide
engagement, the two institutions shall ensure there are
debates at degree-granting higher education campuses
throughout the state. The Legislature emphasizes the
nonpartisan nature of this initiative and expects the two
institutions to coordinate their efforts to foster civic
engagement, voter education, and public discourse
through structured debates and related activities. The
Legislature further intends that these funds not lapse at
the close of FY 2026.

From General Fund, One-time 1,000,000
From Income Tax Fund (555,400)

Pass Through Funding 444,600
The Legislature intends that Talent Ready Utah,
in consultation with and upon recommendation from the
First Credential Oversight Committee established in
First Credential Program (House Bill 260, 2025
General Session) use up to $1,000,000 one-time
appropriated for Higher Education Digital Credentials,
Pathways, and Program Mapping to contract with a
vendor to develop a tool to provide skills portfolios to
students as they earn credentials in public high school
and through higher education certificate or degree
attainment. The Legislature further intends that this tool
ensures that students can track the development of
competencies obtained through coursework,
certifications, apprenticeships, and degrees and how
these competencies align with workforce demands and
potential employers.
The Legislature intends that the $4,000,000
ongoing Income Tax Fund appropriation in "New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations" (Senate Bill 2, 2025
General Session), Item 89, be allocated towards the direct
costs associated with expanding and creating Engineering
and Computer Science degree programs at Utah System
of Higher Education degree-granting institutions. The
Legislature further intends that the Engineering and
Computer Science Initiatives require a one-to-one match
from degree-granting institutions recommended to
receive the funding, and that Talent Ready Utah develop
processes and issue a grant application process to manage
and prioritize the distribution of funds. Institutions
submitting proposals must provide detailed plans for
program expansion or creation, including requested
direct programmatic delivery costs, equipment and
supply needs, curriculum development, use of matching
funds, anticipated student outcomes (enrollment,
completion, relevant placements), industry partnerships,
integration of work-based learning, expected delivery
timelines, and other relevant details. The Legislature
further intends that new investments be directed toward
expanding Engineering and Computer Science offerings,
addressing emerging occupations, and modernizing lab
equipment.

To implement the provisions of First Credential

The Legislature intends that the State Board of
Education, in consultation with and upon
recommendation from the First Credential Oversight
Committee establish the First Credential Program
(House Bill 260, 2025 General Session) to use up to
$2,000,000 one-time appropriated for the expansion of
the Utah First Credential program to contract with a
vendor to develop an online system that offers a
statewide education and career mapping software
platform that is linked to state career opportunities and
offers a career interest aptitude assessment. The
Legislature further intends that the platform serve as a
comprehensive interactive tool for students, parents,
industry, and public educators to map high school
credentials through higher education certificate or degree
attainment.
The Legislature intends that the State Board of
Education use remaining funds appropriated for the Utah
First Credential Expansion funding item be distributed to
local education agencies using a grant process in
alignment with criteria established by the First Credential
Oversight Committee.

Section 3. Effective Date.

(1) Except as provided in Subsection (2), this bill takes effect:

(a) except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), May 7, 2025; or

(b) if approved by two-thirds of all members elected to each house:

(i) upon approval by the governor;

(ii) without the governor's signature, the day following the constitutional time limit of Utah Constitution, Article VII, Section 8; or

(iii) in the case of a veto, the date of veto override.

(2) The actions affecting Section 2 (Effective 07/01/25) take effect on July 1, 2025.

S.B. 3 Enrolled

**Appropriations Adjustments**

2025 GENERAL SESSION

STATE OF UTAH

**Chief Sponsor: Jerry W. Stevenson**

House Sponsor: Val L. Peterson

**LONG TITLE**

**General Description:**

This bill supplements or reduces appropriations otherwise provided for the
support and operation of state government for the fiscal year beginning July
1, 2024 and ending June 30, 2025 and for the fiscal year beginning July 1,
2025 and ending June 30, 2026.

**Highlighted Provisions:**

This bill:

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
state agencies;

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
public education programs;

 provides budget increases and decreases for the use and support of certain
institutions of higher education;

 provides funds for the bills with fiscal impact passed in the 2025 General
Session;

 provides budget increases and decreases for other purposes as described; and

 provides intent language.

**Money Appropriated in this Bill:**

This bill appropriates ($87,406,900) in operating and capital budgets for
fiscal year 2025, including:

 ($13,542,400) from General Fund; and

 $390,600 from Income Tax Fund; and

 ($74,255,100) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($5,630,000) in expendable funds and accounts for
fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this
bill.

This bill appropriates $100,050,400 in business-like activities for fiscal
year 2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $285,000 in restricted fund and account transfers for
fiscal year 2025, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $400 in transfers to unrestricted funds for fiscal year
2025, all of which is from the various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $279,093,100 in operating and capital budgets for
fiscal year 2026, including:

 $46,942,500 from General Fund; and

 ($91,797,600) from Income Tax Fund; and

 $15,322,300 from Uniform School Fund; and

 $308,625,900 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $7,975,800 in expendable funds and accounts for fiscal
year 2026, including:

 $500,000 from General Fund; and

 $7,475,800 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates ($14,027,700) in business-like activities for fiscal
year 2026, including:

 $630,000 from General Fund; and

 ($14,657,700) from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill appropriates $118,318,600 in restricted fund and account transfers
for fiscal year 2026, including:

 $15,731,000 from General Fund; and

 $102,587,600 from Income Tax Fund.

This bill appropriates $842,101,800 in transfers to unrestricted funds for
fiscal year 2026, all of which is from the General Fund.

This bill appropriates $298,813,400 in capital project funds for fiscal year
2026, including:

 $2,000,000 from General Fund; and

 $296,813,400 from various sources as detailed in this bill.

This bill reflects $7,306,100 in higher education budget reporting for fiscal
year 2026.

**Other Special Clauses:**

This bill provides a special effective date.

Section 1 of this bill takes effect immediately. Section 2 of this bill takes
effect on July 1, 2025.

**Uncodified Material Affected:**

ENACTS UNCODIFIED MATERIAL

UNIVERSITY OF UTAH |  |  |   
ITEM 306 | To University of Utah - Education and General |  |   
| From General Fund |  | 16,000,000  
| From General Fund, One-time |  | (28,000)  
| From Income Tax Fund |  | (15,500,000)  
| From Income Tax Fund, One-time |  | 1,330,000  
| Schedule of Programs: |  |   
| Research | 1,500,000 |   
| Public Service | 302,000 |   
| The Legislature intends that the University of |  |   
| Utah use $1,500,000 one-time funding provided by this |  |   
| item to fund a cross-departmental project to incorporate |  |   
| an odometry lab and a proof of concept for |  |   
| communications-based train control on a limited portion |  |   
| of a light rail vehicle line. The goal of this project is to |  |   
| determine the best and most appropriate signaling system |  |   
| for current and future transit operations in the Salt Lake |  |   
| Valley, and to promote a center of excellence at the |  |   
| University of Utah for such systems. |  |   
| The Legislature intends that the appropriations of |  |   
| $300,000 to the University of Utah's Hinckley Institute of |  |   
| Politics and $300,000 to Utah Valley University's Gary |  |   
| R. Herbert Institute for Public Policy be used by the two |  |   
| institutions to collaborate on a proposal to host |  |   
| nonpartisan candidate debates and on establishing a |  |   
| statewide, nonpartisan debate organization. The |  |   
| statewide, nonpartisan debate organization shall be |  |   
| located at the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the |  |   
| University of Utah. This organization shall ensure that |  |   
| candidate debates for federal and statewide elected |  |   
| offices are objective, accessible, and of high quality. To |  |   
| promote broad geographic accessibility and statewide |  |   
| engagement, the two institutions shall ensure there are |  |   
| debates at degree-granting higher education campuses |  |   
| throughout the state. The Legislature emphasizes the |  |   
| nonpartisan nature of this initiative and expects the two |  |   
| institutions to coordinate their efforts to foster civic |  |   
| engagement, voter education, and public discourse |  |   
| through structured debates and related activities. The |  |   
| Legislature further intends that these funds not lapse at |  |   
| the close of FY 2026. |  |

| The Legislature intends that Talent Ready Utah, |  |   
| in consultation with and upon recommendation from the |  |   
| First Credential Oversight Committee established in |  |   
| First Credential Program (House Bill 260, 2025 |  |   
| General Session) use up to $1,000,000 one-time |  |   
| appropriated for Higher Education Digital Credentials, |  |   
| Pathways, and Program Mapping to contract with a |  |   
| vendor to develop a tool to provide skills portfolios to |  |   
| students as they earn credentials in public high school |  |   
| and through higher education certificate or degree |  |   
| attainment. The Legislature further intends that this tool |  |   
| ensures that students can track the development of |  |   
| competencies obtained through coursework, |  |   
| certifications, apprenticeships, and degrees and how |  |   
| these competencies align with workforce demands and |  |   
| potential employers. |  |   
| The Legislature intends that the $4,000,000 |  |   
| ongoing Income Tax Fund appropriation in "New Fiscal Year Supplemental Appropriations" (Senate Bill 2, 2025 |  |   
| General Session), Item 89, be allocated towards the direct |  |   
| costs associated with expanding and creating Engineering |  |   
| and Computer Science degree programs at Utah System |  |   
| of Higher Education degree-granting institutions. The |  |   
| Legislature further intends that the Engineering and |  |   
| Computer Science Initiatives require a one-to-one match |  |   
| from degree-granting institutions recommended to |  |   
| receive the funding, and that Talent Ready Utah develop |  |   
| processes and issue a grant application process to manage |  |   
| and prioritize the distribution of funds. Institutions |  |   
| submitting proposals must provide detailed plans for |  |   
| program expansion or creation, including requested |  |   
| direct programmatic delivery costs, equipment and |  |   
| supply needs, curriculum development, use of matching |  |   
| funds, anticipated student outcomes (enrollment, |  |   
| completion, relevant placements), industry partnerships, |  |   
| integration of work-based learning, expected delivery |  |   
| timelines, and other relevant details. The Legislature |  |   
| further intends that new investments be directed toward |  |   
| expanding Engineering and Computer Science offerings, |  |   
| addressing emerging occupations, and modernizing lab |  |   
| equipment. |  |

The Legislature has reviewed the following expendable funds. The Legislature

accounts as indicated. Outlays and expenditures from the funds or accounts to
which the money is transferred may be made without further legislative action,
in accordance with statutory provisions relating to the funds or accounts.

Section 3. **Effective Date.**

_(1) Except as provided in Subsection (2), this bill takes effect:_

_(a) except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), May 7, 2025; or_

_(b) if approved by two-thirds of all members elected to each house:_

_(i) upon approval by the governor;_

_(ii) without the governor 's signature, the day following the constitutional
time limit of Utah Constitution, Article VII, Section 8; or_

_(iii) in the case of a veto, the date of veto override._

_(2) The actions affecting Section 2 (Effective 07/01/25) take effect on July
1, 2025._
